_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The purpose of the Whole Foods Market Process Safety Management Program is to assist with the prevention of accidental releases of toxic and substances that can cause harm to the public, facility employees, and to the environment.

The Whole Foods Process Safety Management Program is designed to comply with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulations detailed 29 CFR 1910.119, and the Environmental Protection Agency regulations in 40 CFR Part 68.  The stationary source is the ammonia refrigeration system located at the Whole Foods Distribution Center400 E. Johnson Ave., Cheshire, CT.  Whole Foods has enacted both the Process Safety Management Program and the Risk Management Program as part of their dedication to the health and safety of their employees, as well as the additional community and public receptors.  The only regulated substance at this facility is anhydrous ammonia, which is classified as a toxic substance, liquefied under pressure.  

This facility is a warehousing distribution center with cold storage capabilities.  The refrigeration system encompasses three separate ammonia machinery rooms, and has a combined inventory of approximately 16,198 pounds of anhydrous ammonia stored on site.  This process meets the requirements of EPA's Program 3.

This Process Safety Program Manual has been developed by HCG Associates on behalf of the Whole Foods Distribution Center, specifically to prevent or mitigate accidental releases associated with the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia at the Cheshire facility. As noted in specific sections, portions of this Plan, including technical details associated with anhydrous ammonia operations were prepared by the American Refrigeration Company, Andover, MA. This manual was developed to meet the requirements of both the OSHA Process Safety Management Program, and the Risk Management Program regulations and is available to government agencies and the public for review.

Whole Foods. operates the 155,000-sq

. ft., 400 E. Johnson Ave. facility on an approximately 40 acre industrially zoned parcel in Cheshire, CT. There have been no accidental releases within the past 5 year period.



  The Whole Foods PSM program consists of the following 15 elements:

?    Introduction

?    Employee Participation

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Contractor Qualifications

?    Pre-Start Up Safety Review

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Management of Change

?    Incident Investigation

?    Emergency Planning and Response

?    Compliance Audits

?    Trade Secrets
